data.title: Be the Cowboy
data.meta_description: "Be the Cowboy" is the fifth album by American artist Mitski, released on August 17th 2018 through the label Dead Oceans. Musically, though the use of traditional indie rock guitar and synth is present, synths are more prominent and there is a return to the use of horns seen on Retired from Sad...
data.text:
"Be the Cowboy" is the fifth album by American artist Mitski, released on August 17th 2018 through the label Dead Oceans.

Background[]

Musically, though the use of traditional indie rock guitar and synth is present, synths are more prominent and there is a return to the use of horns seen on Retired from Sad. The choice to move away from distorted guitar was deliberate, because “that became something people recognized me for, and I wanted to make sure I didn’t repeat myself or unintentionally create a signature sound.”[1], as well as there being an effort to "figure out ways to pace a song that wasn’t reliant on classic song form."[2]

Lyrically, the use of characters and metaphors to convey feelings is expanded on significantly from Puberty 2; Mitski has expressed frustration several times over the way that people assume (especially of female songwriters) that songwriting "pours out", rather than being a learnt skill. Linked to this, Mitski experimented in the use of narrative on Be the Cowboy- though full characters are not described through songs, Mitski has outlined the idea of:

“a very controlled icy repressed woman who is starting to unravel. Because women have so little power and showing emotion is seen as weakness, this ‘character’ clings to any amount of control she can get. Still, there is something very primordial in her that is trying to find a way to get out.”[3]

Be the Cowboy was written partially while on tour as well as after touring for Puberty 2 had finished (being recorded “little by little in multiple studios between tours”),[4] and as such Mitski saw the album as a process of reconnecting with herself emotionally:

"A lot of this record was me not having any feelings, being completely spent but then trying to rally myself and wake up and get back to Mitski."[5]

A strong artistic theme throughout the album is yearning for what cannot be had either because it no longer exists or never existed- notably, in Nobody and Washing Machine Heart, by making reference to movies (the music video of the latter featuring the character of a "Silent Film Star"). What is desired is represented by the highly glamourised fiction seen in films; Mitski has often talked about the strong influence films had on her early life.

Tracklist[]

No. Title Length 1. Geyser 02:23 2. Why Didn't You Stop Me? 02:21 3. Old Friend 01:52 4. A Pearl 02:36 5. Lonesome Love 01:50 6. Remember My Name 02:15 7. Me and My Husband 02:17 8. Come into the Water 01:32 9. Nobody 03:13 10. Pink in the Night 02:16 11. A Horse Named Cold Air 02:03 12. Washing Machine Heart 02:08 13. Blue Light 01:43 14. Two Slow Dancers 03:59 Japanese Bonus Tracks 15. Geyser (Demo) 1:54 16. Why Didn't You Stop Me? (ほうじ茶バージョン) 2:23

Singles[]

Geyser - May 14th 2018, along with a music video and album being made available for preorder without any prior announcements[6]

Nobody - June 26th 2018, alongside a music video[7]

Two Slow Dancers - August 9th 2018[8]

Music Videos[]

Geyser - Directed by Zia Anger, starring Mitski. Premiered May 14th 2018[9]

Nobody - Directed by Christopher Good, starring Mitski. Premiered June 26th 2018[10]

Washing Machine Heart - Directed by Zia Anger, starring Mitski and Michael Cavadias (as "Silent Film Star"). Premiered November 8th 2018[11]

A Pearl - Directed by Saad Moosajee and Art Camp, co-directed by Danae Gosset. 3D Animation by Saad Moosajee and Cel Animation by Danae Gosset. Premiered January 31st 2019[12]

Critical Reception[]

Be the Cowboy has a score of 87/100 based on 30 aggregated critic reviews on Metacritic, indicating universal acclaim.[13]

Accolades:[]

Publication Accolade Year Rank Ref. Billboard 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 11 [14] Consequence of Sound The Top 50 Albums of 2018 2018 1 [15] Entertainment Weekly 20 Best Albums of 2018 2018 4 [16] Flavorwire The 25 Best Albums of 2018 2018 12 [17] Flood Magazine The Best Albums of 2018 2018 1 [18] Fopp 100 Best Albums of 2018 2018 46 [19] The Guardian The 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 5 [20] The Independent The 40 Best Albums of 2018 2018 24 [21] The Line of Best Fit The Best Albums of 2018 2018 1 [22] The New York Times The 28 Best Albums of 2018 2018 2 [23] Noisey The 100 Best Albums of 2018 2018 34 [24] Now The 10 Best Albums of 2018 2018 5 [25] NPR The 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 2 [26] Paste The 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 6 [27] Pitchfork The 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 1 [28] The 200 Best Albums of the 2010s 2019 64 [29] Recording Academy GRAMMY for Best Recording Package* 2018 Nominated [30] Refinery 29 The 10 Best Albums of 2018 2018 8 [31] Rolling Stone 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 14 [32] The Skinny Top 50 Albums of 2018 2018 3 [33] Slant Magazine The 25 Best Albums of 2018 2018 7 [34] Stereogum The 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 10 [35] Time The 10 Best Albums of 2018 2018 3 [36] Uproxx The 50 Best Albums of 2018 2018 39 [37] Vulture The 15 Best Albums of 2018 2018 1 [38] The Village Voice Pazz & Jop: The Top 100 Albums of 2018 2018 3 [39]

*The GRAMMY nomination was for Mary Banas, the designer of the album packaging, rather than the album itself.

Physical Releases[]

Be the Cowboy was issued on vinyl and CD through Dead Oceans upon release in 2018, including a coke bottle clear vinyl available with the Dead Oceans Mail Order Bundle or just a poster and a deluxe red vinyl pressing available through Vinyl Me Please which included a 12 page full color booket and a 12x12 inch art print by Charlotte Mei.[40] In 2019 a bonus track edition was released exclusively in Japan on CD and a "Wine Red" pressing that comes with a download code for the bonus tracks.[41]

The Dead Oceans Mail Order Bundle included:

'Be The Cowboy’ LP on limited edition “Coke Bottle Green” vinyl in a gatefold jacket, packaged with 27” x 39” poster.

One 100% silk handkerchief, randomly selected from 2 limited edition Mitski designs. (corresponding sets of lyrics from "A Horse Named Cold Air")[42]

'Be The Cowboy' on CD in 6-panel wallet

Instant download of “Geyser"

100 copies sold by Newbury Comics came with a signed poster and Polaroids. In 2021 a white cassette and a smoke cassette varient were released exclusively through Retrospekt. On July 26th 2023 a Urban Outfitters exclusive gold vinyl (limited to 5000 copies) was released.

Album photoshoot by Bao Ngo (2018)[]

Credits[]

Personnel[]

Songwriting, Performance - Mitski

Performance, Production, "Ripping Sax Solo" on track 6 - Patrick Hyland

Horns (except sax solo on track 6) - Philly Phatness: Thor Espanez, Ian Gray, Vince Tampio

Bass (track 9) - Evan Marien

Mastering - Ted Jensen

Packaging Design - Mary Banas

Photography - Bao Ngo

Carl Knight – lighting

Annika White – styling

Marika Aoki – makeup

Recorded in Retro City Studios, Philadelphia, PA, Gradwell House Studios, Haddon Heights, NJ and Red Bull Studios, Los Angeles, CA

Trivia[]

The album title comes from Mitski jokingly saying “Be the cowboy you wish to see the world” to herself as a reminder not to be subservient and people pleasing above her own needs, instead to sometimes ask “Well, what would a cowboy do?”[43]

Mitski started to write Geyser while in college, making it the song she has spent the longest writing[44]

Geyser has also been performed live as early 2014

The attention to detail in the packaging is seriously impressive, resulting in Be the Cowboy's designer Mary Banasgarnering a Grammy nomination for best album packaging (losing out to St Vincent's Masseduction designed by Willo Perron).[45]
